On Mon, Sep 21, 2009 at 3:40 AM, Sebastien Lambla <seb@...> wrote:
>
> The original URLs used + as a shorthand for spaces in querystrings. Browsers still implement this feature. Sadly, neither http nor html (except for app/www-url-formencoded used as querystring in the HTML5 spec) imply this should still apply.
>
> Hence my question. Should an HTTP framework decode those + by default for any http URI? I'm a bit split on the issue, as I don't want to implement non-standard features, but I also don't want to p*ss off my users.
>

I would think you'd want to decode + to space ONLY when it is part of
a query string.

http://www.foo.com/a+b?c=d+e

The plus sign in "a+b" is literal, the client really did intend to
send a plus sign.

The second one in "d+e" is an escaped space.
